profileText: A Representative from Virginia; born in Inglewood, Mecklenburg County, Va., September 16, 1798; completed preparatory studies and was graduated from the College of William and Mary, Williamsburg, Va., in 1819; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1821 and commenced practice in Boydton, Mecklenburg County, Va.; served in the State house of delegates in 1822 and 1824-1832; member of the State constitutional convention in 1829 and 1830; unsuccessful candidate for election in 1832 to the Twenty-third Congress; again served in the State house of delegates in 1839, 1840, 1845, 1846, and 1852; served as speaker three terms; elected as a Democrat to the Twenty-seventh Congress (March 4, 1841-March 3, 1843); was not a candidate for renomination; delegate to the State constitutional convention in 1850; again elected to the Thirty-third and three succeeding Congresses and served from March 4, 1853, until his death in Boydton, Va., July 3, 1859; chairman, Committee on District of Columbia (Thirty-fifth Congress); interment on his estate, ``Wheatland,'' near Boydton, Va.

researchRecord.name: 1854, 3 pages.
researchRecord.description: One letter from William Osborne Goode to James C. Dobbin is in reference to a midshipman's appointment for William C. Whittle, Jr. The second letter is William Goode's acceptance for a dinner invitation.

researchRecord.name: In the Shelton Hardaway Short Papers, 1971-1988, 77 pages.
researchRecord.description: Includes information on William Osborne Goode who authored the Randolph-Macon College charter, as well as information on William Goode's plantation home "Wheatland."

researchRecord.name: In the Virginia Politicians' and Authors' Papers, 1806-1902, 64 pages.
researchRecord.description: Correspondents include William Osborne Goode. An inventory to the papers is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: n.d., 4 volumes.
researchRecord.description: These four scrapbooks include speeches, letters from grandchildren and other descendents, photographs, maps of "Wheatland" and published excerpts of William O. Goode collected by Shelton H. Short, III.
